author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Our Days Have Always Been Running Out
description: I greet autumn with a stillness I never felt when I was younger and in such a hurry.
content: NASHVILLE — Autumn light is the loveliest light there is. Soft, forgiving, it makes all the world an illuminated dream. Dust motes catch fire, and bright specks drift down from the trees and lift up from the stirred soil, floating over lawns and woodland paths and ordinary roofs and parking lots. It’s an unchoreographed aerial dance, a celebration of what happens when light marries earth and sky. Autumn light always makes me think of fiery motes of chalk dust drifting in the expectant hush of an elementary school classroom during story time, just before the bell rings and sets the children free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman, Ben Shpigel and Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Week 2: Injuries Abound and the Chargers Push Mahomes’s Chiefs
description: Kansas City needed fourth-quarter heroics and a 58-yard field goal in overtime to push past rookie quarterback Justin Herbert and the Los Angeles Chargers.
content: Week 2’s early games featured injuries and injury scares before a few ended with wild finishes. Unlikely heroes came up clutch and some teams that were expected to look shaky before the season began — hi, Bears and Rams — stormed out to 2-0 records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: Emmy Winners 2020: The Full List of Awards
description: Here are the shows, actors and production teams who won at the 72nd Primetime Emmy Awards.
content: “Schitt’s Creek” broke a record with seven Primetime awards and nine Emmys in total in the comedy categories, and “Succession” took home five awards, including best drama series. Here are other notable moments from the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Spiced, seared eggplant, crispy tofu and seared scallops: These are the ingredients to savor as summer turns to fall.
content: Good morning. The passage of the seasons is different this year, and not just because of the ferocity of the weather and the fires, amplified by climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Agency’
description: From an office building in Russia, an army of “trolls” tried to wreak havoc all around the internet — and in real-life American communities.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Augustín and Frances Robles
title: Cuba’s Economy Was Hurting. The Pandemic Brought a Food Crisis.
description: The island was able to control the coronavirus, but the dearth of tourists in the pandemic’s wake strangled an economy already damaged by mismanagement and U.S. sanctions.
content: HAVANA — It was a lucky day for the unemployed tourism guide in Havana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and David McCabe
title: ‘There’s No There There’: What the TikTok Deal Achieved
description: The agreement for the social media app falls short of President Trump’s promises.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The saga of TikTok had everything: Ominous threats of surveillance. A forced fire sale. Threats of retaliation. Head-spinning deal terms that morphed by the hour. Dark horse bidders and a looming deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Top U.S. Health Officials Tiptoe Around Trump’s Vaccine Timeline
description: The administration’s experts tried to find a way to support both the president and the reality of scientific and medical constraints he doesn’t always recognize.
content: As the nation’s coronavirus death toll neared 200,000, top administration health officials on Sunday delicately sidestepped President Trump’s ambitious declaration last week that a coronavirus vaccine would be available for every American by April.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 21, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
title: Trump Supporters Disrupt Early Voting in Virginia
description: A group waving Trump flags and chanting “four more years” created a commotion at a polling location in Fairfax, Va. A county official said some voters and staff members felt intimidated.
content: A group of Trump supporters waving campaign flags disrupted the second day of early voting in Fairfax, Va., on Saturday, chanting “four more years” as voters entered a polling location and, at one point, forming a line that voters had to walk around outside the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: In Belarus, Russian Mercenaries Turned From Saboteurs to Friends
description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko accused Russia of sending a group of mercenaries to disrupt his re-election. With mass protests consuming the country after the vote, he briskly changed his tune.
content: ZHDANOVICHI, Belarus — Members of the Wagner Group, a shadowy Russian mercenary force linked to an associate of President Vladimir V. Putin, have left their traces around the world. They fought in support of pro-Russian separatists in Eastern Ukraine; helped tilt Syria’s civil war in favor of President Bashar al-Assad and fought on the side of a Kremlin-backed warlord in Libya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
title: Abortion Was Back-Burnered in the Presidential Race. Not Anymore.
description: The battle over the Supreme Court brings back a volatile issue with political risks for both sides, even as it energizes parts of their bases.
content: For Joshua Hon, the prospect of another open seat on the Supreme Court was the moment he’s been waiting for since voting for President Trump four years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Fire Lessons From Australia’s South Coast
description: Australia’s South Coast was hammered by last year’s fires. Now it’s time to prepare for another fire season.
content: By this time last year, I had already written my first bush fire story of the season — with a headline that called the destruction of the Binna Burra Lodge an omen of the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Celtics Got Angry After Game 2. It Worked, to the Heat’s Dismay.
description: Whatever happened in the locker room after blowing a lead in Game 2, the Celtics regrouped and hung on for the win in Game 3, 117-106.
content: Maybe the Boston Celtics should argue some more?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Adam Liptak
title: To Conservatives, Barrett Has ‘Perfect Combination’ of Attributes for Supreme Court
description: Judge Amy Coney Barrett is regarded as the leading contender to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: Two years ago, after nominating Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court, President Trump strongly hinted that his choice for the next opening would be a former law professor he had named to a federal appeals court the year before: Judge Amy Coney Barrett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Serge F. Kovaleski and Jacey Fortin
title: With Flags, Crosses and Photos, Mourning 200,000 Dead
description: Those left behind must grieve in a country still firmly gripped by the coronavirus pandemic. Everywhere they turn, there is a reminder of their pain.
content: Twelve days after his wife died of the coronavirus, increasing the enormous toll in the United States by one, Michael Davis, dazed and grieving, went back to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Allyson Waller
title: Tropical Storm Beta, Forecast to Move Inland Monday, Churns in the Gulf
description: The storm is headed for the Texas and Louisiana coast, another blow for states in the Gulf that have been hit by five other storms this hurricane season.
content: As Tropical Storm Beta stirred in the Gulf of Mexico, several warnings were issued Sunday across sections of the Texas and Louisiana coast still reeling from damage by Hurricanes Laura and Sally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: The Pros and Cons of Swimming With a Hammer Head
description: A new study suggests that the ocean’s strangest-looking headgear is difficult to tote around.
content: People joke about asking horses, “Why the long face?” We should redirect this question to hammerhead sharks. Their famous head extensions, called cephalofoils, can measure three feet from eye to eye. And scientists are still trying to nail down exactly what purposes they serve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Persily and Charles Stewart III
title: With Six Weeks to the Election, Six Ways to Protect It
description: Step 1: Know how and when you’re going to vote.
content: The 2020 election is underway. Not just the campaign — the actual voting has already begun. States are recruiting and training poll workers, identifying the final list of polling places and early voting locations and mailing out ballots. The pandemic presents a huge challenge, but we can still ensure a safe and accessible vote this November. Here are six ways to make that happen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Updates: Biden Says Election Winner Should Pick Nominee
description: Lawmakers spar over the process to fill the vacant seat on the Supreme Court as possible nominees start to come into view and mourners continue to grieve a giant of the law.
content: This briefing is no longer being updated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: The Age of Electric Cars Is Dawning Ahead of Schedule
description: Battery prices are dropping faster than expected. Analysts are moving up projections of when an electric vehicle won’t need government incentives to be cheaper than a gasoline model.
content: FRANKFURT — An electric Volkswagen ID.3 for the same price as a Golf. A Tesla Model 3 that costs as much as a BMW 3 Series. A Renault Zoe electric subcompact whose monthly lease payment might equal a nice dinner for two in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: TikTok’s Last-Minute Save
description: Amazon is hiring (again), while Walmart is doling out raises.
content: Hi, everyone. Here’s your quick catch-up on the latest news in business and tech, plus what you need to know for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbe R. Gluck and Gillian E. Metzger
title: ‘Her Black Coffee Always Brewed Strong’
description: We clerked for Ruth Bader Ginsburg. In her career and at home, she lived a life that reflected her vision of equality.
content: There was our justice, Ruth Bader Ginsburg: “At the end of the day, the government is throwing to the wind the women’s entitlement. …” She was forcefully intervening at oral argument in the last months of her life, in a case about access to contraception under the Affordable Care Act. Her dissent, issued in July, condemned the majority for leaving potentially half a million women to “fend for themselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘As I Turned Around, I Saw the Woman in the Colorful Jacket’
description: A trip to a museum gift shop, a memorable day on Putnam Avenue and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: Dallas Gets Goals From Unlikely Sources in Win Over Lightning
description: Defensemen Joel Hanley and Jamie Oleksiak each scored in the Stars’ 4-1 win, as Dallas took a 1-0 lead in the series over Tampa Bay.
content: EDMONTON, Alberta — The Dallas Stars have drawn first blood as two of the N.H.L.’s southernmost franchises compete for a championship inside the league’s so-called bubble in the league’s northernmost city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 20, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 20, 2020.
content: A picture caption with an article on Page 4 about the archive of rehearsal tapes of the choreographer Trisha Brown, using information provided by the publicist, misidentified the dancer with Brown in “Leaning Duets II.” She is Carol Goodden, not Sylvia Palacios.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: W.N.B.A. Postpones Storm-Lynx Game Over Coronavirus Concerns
description: Some Seattle Storm players received inconclusive virus test results before Game 1 of their semifinal series against the Minnesota Lynx on Sunday. The game was postponed.
content: The opener of the W.N.B.A. semifinal playoff series between the Seattle Storm and the Minnesota Lynx was postponed nearly 90 minutes before its scheduled tipoff Sunday because of inconclusive coronavirus test results for Storm players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How the G.O.P. Might Get to Yes on Replacing Ruth Bader Ginsburg
description: There’s no escape from juristocracy except through political conflict.
content: Imagine a Republican senator uncertain whether to vote for the Supreme Court nominee that President Trump is poised to put forward. He is part of a select group, our senator; perhaps we can even guess how many children and grandchildren he has, how steeply his hair still rises from his brow, how close he once came to being president himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Supreme Court Fight Could Scramble Intense Battle for Senate
description: Republicans see benefits for candidates struggling in conservative states, but Democrats say the vacancy sharpens their health care message and underscores Republican fealty to Trump.
content: Senator Kelly Loeffler, a Georgia Republican in a tough fight to win the seat to which she was appointed in 2019, raced after Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death on Friday to declare that she would back President Trump in filling the Supreme Court seat just weeks before Americans went to the polls. And she wanted voters to know that she didn’t hesitate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: 8 Picture Books About Ordinary Kids’ Everyday Activism
description: From making soup to creating a butterfly garden, everyone can do something.
content: 111 TREES: How One Village Celebrates the Birth of Every Girl
source.name: The New York Times

title: Health Officials Tiptoe Around Trump’s Coronavirus Vaccine Timeline
description: New Zealand says it will ease its virus measures. Lockdowns return as Europe faces a second wave.
content: Residents of Madrid took to the streets on Sunday to protest the renewed lockdown of dozens of areas across the Spanish capital, largely in working-class suburbs that are most densely populated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: How California Became Ground Zero for Climate Disasters
description: The engineering and land management that enabled the state’s tremendous growth have left it more vulnerable to climate shocks — and those shocks are getting worse.
content: California is one of America’s marvels. By moving vast quantities of water and suppressing wildfires for decades, the state has transformed its arid and mountainous landscape into the richest, most populous and bounteous place in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump Seeks to Turn Israeli-Arab Accords Into Campaign Gains
description: President Trump’s re-election campaign lost no time turning a White House ceremony into a television ad, as it targets Jewish and evangelical voters.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Trump presided over a grandiose White House signing ceremony for new accords between Israel and two Arab states last week, his re-election campaign wasted little time cashing in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: ‘I Was Devastated. Now I Am Emboldened.’
description: Readers share their thoughts and condolences after the passing of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: Since the passing of Ruth Bader Ginsburg on Friday, readers have used the comments sections of Opinion pieces to express not only their grief, but also their anger and fear about what her loss means for the future of the Supreme Court, the outcome of the U.S. presidential election and Democratic ideals in general. “It feels like the end of justice,” wrote M.K. in Germany. Marika H. in Santa Monica, Calif., wrote, “Our already-fragile democracy should have never depended on a single heartbeat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle and Michael Gonchar
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Supreme Court’s Feminist Icon, Is Dead at 87’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the life and legacy of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg — including how she not only changed the law, but how she also transformed the roles of men and women in society.
content: Featured Article: “Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Supreme Court’s Feminist Icon, Is Dead at 87” by Linda Greenhouse
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Rough Play or Bad Intentions? Orca Encounters Off Iberia Baffle Experts
description: Nobody knows why the marine mammals have been ramming boats in waters from Gibraltar to Galicia, Spain, in recent months. Some vessels were so badly damaged that they had to be towed to port.
content: The dark shapes briefly surfaced near the boat sailing in the darkness off the coast of northern Spain, then there was a thud, followed by an expletive in Spanish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Outside the Supreme Court, Mourners Honor Ginsburg’s Legacy
description: People of all ages flocked on Saturday to the building in Washington, leaving flowers, posters and messages scrawled in chalk.
content: WASHINGTON — Droves of mourners outside the Supreme Court paid their respects on Saturday to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Friday at 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Subway Car Derails After Object Thrown on Tracks, Police Say
description: Three people had minor injuries after an A train jumped the tracks at the 14th Street station. A Bronx man was charged in connection with the derailment, officials said.
content: Three people sustained minor injuries Sunday morning after a northbound A train struck an object thrown on the tracks and derailed, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Zero Cost House’ Review: Could Thoreau Save Us Now?
description: In the dreamscape of Toshiki Okada’s play, the American philosopher is a 21st-century presence, and an author meets his younger self.
content: For an enduring figure in the American canon, Henry David Thoreau is needier than you might think. When this relic of the 1800s shows up in Toshiki Okada’s probing, funny, hugely resonant play “Zero Cost House,” he is insecure about his 21st-century status. It’s pretty clear he’s been keeping close tabs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Behrouz Boochani
title: ‘White Australia’ Policy Lives On in Immigrant Detention
description: The government’s abuse of refugees in offshore facilities on Nauru and Papua New Guinea has its roots in the country’s racist, colonial history.
content: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — Growing up in a Kurdish family in the Ilam Province of Iran, I never expected my life to be affected by Australia’s history of white supremacy and settler colonialism. I had little awareness of Australia, a faraway country founded as a penal colony, and built on the massacres of its Indigenous people and on European migration. It was to be decades before I would hear about the White Australia policy, an official state immigration policy, in effect between 1901 and 1973, barring nonwhite people from immigrating to the country and intent on making Australia a white nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Sandra Stevenson
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, TikTok, Emmys: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: As Supreme Court Fight Heats Up, Biden Urges Republican Senators to ‘Follow Your Conscience’
description: The Democratic nominee, speaking in Philadelphia, said the Senate should wait until after the election to decide on the nominee to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. urged Republicans on Sunday not to rush a Supreme Court nominee through the Senate in the final six weeks before the presidential election, suggesting that such a move would amount to an “abuse of power” at an already perilous moment in American political history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here’s a Full List of the 2020 Emmy Nominees
description: The 72nd Emmy Awards will be held tonight. Several winners were announced last week.
content: Netflix and HBO’s “Watchmen” dominated the 2020 Emmy nominations, which were announced on July 28. The Emmy Awards ceremony will be held tonight and broadcast on ABC beginning at 8 p.m. Eastern. It will be hosted by Jimmy Kimmel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero, Manny Fernandez and Marc Santora
title: ‘We May Be Surprised Again’: An Unpredictable Pandemic Takes a Terrible Toll
description: At least 73 countries are seeing surges in newly detected cases, and in regions where cold weather is approaching, worries are mounting.
content: It is a staggering toll, almost 200,000 people dead from the coronavirus in the United States, and nearly five times that many — close to one million people — around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Murkowski Becomes 2nd Republican to Oppose Supreme Court Vote Before Election
description: The announcement by the senator from Alaska potentially complicates efforts to quickly fill the vacancy left by the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Lisa Murkowski said on Sunday that she would not support a confirmation vote to fill the Supreme Court vacancy left by the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg before the November election, becoming the second Republican senator to voice an objection and potentially complicating efforts to swiftly fill the seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: A New York Clock That Told Time Now Tells the Time Remaining
description: Metronome’s digital clock in Manhattan, has been reprogrammed to illustrate a critical window for action to prevent the effects of global warming from becoming irreversible.
content: For more than 20 years, Metronome, which includes a 62-foot-wide 15-digit electronic clock that faces Union Square in Manhattan, has been one of the city’s most prominent and baffling public art projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: One Depleted Team Played Well Sunday (Hint: Not the Jets)
description: The San Francisco 49ers lost two stalwarts from their defensive line, their starting quarterback and running back on Sunday. The Jets still couldn’t challenge.
content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Even without fans in the stands, cheerleaders on the sidelines or the national anthem performed live, some N.F.L. traditions have proven pandemic-proof. Like this one: Two games into the season, and the Jets are already making their fans wish football hadn’t returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden Has $466 Million in Bank, and a Huge Financial Edge on Trump
description: The former vice president and the Democrats were $187 million behind President Trump and the Republicans this spring. Now they are entering the final stretch of the campaign with a $141 million advantage.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign said on Sunday that it entered September with $466 million in the bank together with the Democratic Party, providing Mr. Biden a vast financial advantage of about $141 million over President Trump heading into the intense final stretch of the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Bryson DeChambeau Wins U.S. Open His Way: In Commanding Fashion
description: DeChambeau, who bulked up and went all in to prove a power game could flout golf’s norms, shot the only under-par round on Sunday to win the 2020 U.S. Open.
content: MAMARONECK, N.Y. — The most repeated, and accepted, prediction before the 2020 United States Open at Winged Foot Golf Club was that the golf course would overwhelm the field with its time-honored combination of elusive fairways and punishing rough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Davis
title: This Year’s U.S. Open Spotlights Ben Hogan’s Claim to a Fifth
description: Hogan won the 1942 Hale America Open, which included qualifying rounds during World War II. He always believed it should have counted as his fifth U.S. Open victory.
content: For almost 100 years, the hallmark of the United States Open has been the qualifying procedure. It’s integral to the very nature of the Open, as the tournament is open to all comers — provided they have an official handicap index of 1.4 or better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Lace Collar Wasn’t an Accessory, It Was a Gauntlet
description: Also, a signature. And a symbol, with all sorts of meanings woven into each choice.
content: In 2014, the Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the pioneering legal mind and advocate for equal treatment of the sexes who died on Friday, did something that probably none of her male colleagues were ever asked to do: she gave a tour of her office closet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Emily Flitter
title: Banks Suspected Illegal Activity, but Processed Big Transactions Anyway
description: A leak of thousands of “suspicious activity reports” that banks filed with regulators shows the widespread nature of illicit money flows.
content: A cache of thousands of reports that major banks filed with federal regulators shows that they helped suspected terrorists, drug dealers and corrupt foreign officials move trillions of dollars around the world, despite the banks’ concerns about the suspicious nature of the transactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Emmys Toast ‘Watchmen’ and ‘Schitt’s Creek’ as Stars Stay Home
description: HBO’s ‘Succession’ won best drama. But ‘Schitt’s Creek,’ which swept the comedy awards, and ‘Watchmen,’ with its socially resonant themes, stole the show.
content: “Succession,” HBO’s chronicle of a treacherous, ultrarich media dynasty, won best drama series at the 72nd Emmy Awards on Sunday. It was the fifth time in the last six years that HBO has taken television’s most prestigious prize, and the win helped give the cable network bragging rights over its main Emmys rival of recent years, Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: ‘These Are Real People Dying’: Why an Artist Filled His Yard With Flags
description: Shane Reilly plants a flag for each Texan who dies of the coronavirus. As the national death toll nears 200,000, The New York Times used an image of his memorial to illustrate the staggering scale of loss.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: ‘Faith Healer’ Review: Michael Sheen Stirs the Embers in the Ashes
description: In this enthralling streaming production of Brian Friel’s 1979 play, an itinerant miracle worker is grounded in a gritty reality.
content: The first time I ever saw Michael Sheen, he was blazing like the sun. He was 30 then, making his Broadway debut as a divinely inspired, impishly behaved Mozart in the 1999 revival of Peter Shaffer’s “Amadeus.” He gave such undiluted radiance to a young composer’s brilliance that he eclipsed everyone else onstage, and it felt almost dangerous to stare at him for too long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Tour de France Crowns Young Champion to Close Its Pandemic Edition
description: Riding into Paris a day after grabbing the lead, Tadej Pogacar, 21, was still struggling to fathom how he had claimed his victory over two unforgettable days.
content: Tadej Pogacar on Sunday became the youngest winner of the Tour de France in the post-World War II era, rolling into Paris a day after he took the leader’s yellow jersey off the shoulders of his friend and rival Primoz Roglic in an epic time trial that rewrote the ending of a one-of-a-kind, pandemic-delayed edition of the world’s most famous cycling race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Voting Alone
description: The national bard of community long warned about what isolation would do to us. Now our democracy is in the midst of an experiment no one asked for.
content: From his back deck in southwestern New Hampshire, Robert D. Putnam sees his yard slope past a few hardwood trees and an overturned canoe down to a pond, beyond which looms Mount Monadnock, one of Henry David Thoreau’s favorite peaks to hike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, WeChat, Thai protests: Here’s what you need to know.
content: The U.S. is mourning the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the deeply admired Supreme Court justice who died on Friday. Her death has set the stage for a polarizing battle to replace her on the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Question From an Owl
description: Daniel Larsen opens our solving week, after closing our previous one.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s fairly common to see two-person collaborations in crossword puzzle construction, and once in a while we have solved a group collaboration by the crossword class at J.A.S.A., which is taught by the constructors Andy Kravis and Natan Last.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Matthew Wolff Leads Bryson DeChambeau at U.S. Open as Power Paves the Way
description: A fast start and some steady nerves gave Wolff a two-shot lead entering the final round of only his second major championship.
content: MAMARONECK, N.Y. — In May, with most global sports competitions suspended because of the coronavirus pandemic, the veteran golfers Dustin Johnson, Rory McIlroy and Rickie Fowler competed in a made-for-TV charity match. Almost as a lark, or perhaps to lure a younger audience, Matthew Wolff, a 21-year-old PGA Tour newcomer, was invited to play, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Associated Press
title: Aimless Giants Lose Saquon Barkley, Then the Game
description: Giants’ final drive ended with an offensive pass interference call on receiver Golden Tate.
content: CHICAGO (AP) — The Chicago Bears were happy with another close win, while the Giants have greater concerns than their 0-2 record: a potentially serious injury to star running back Saquon Barkley.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Mourners Fill Court’s Plaza to Remember
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 20, 2020.
content: “We, as citizens, have a responsibility to mourn her, and stand together and show that we care about human life, which is something I think we’ve lost in the last six months.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: For Women, the Death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg Brings a Particular Grief
description: Quite apart from the politics surrounding Justice Ginsburg’s death and the fight over her replacement, women of all ages are feeling the loss of a role model.
content: WASHINGTON — In Waco, Texas, Lily Coffman, 15, donned her handmade “R.B.G.” coronavirus mask and “dissent collar” earrings on Saturday night and joined a small crowd of mostly mothers and daughters in a candlelight vigil at the county courthouse. There, they held an 87-second moment of silence — a second for each year of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: A TV Drama on China’s Fight With Covid-19 Draws Ire Over Its Depiction of Women
description: A scene from a state-sponsored show extolled men who volunteered but played down women’s contributions. Internet users are calling for the show to be pulled from the air.
content: The scene came seven minutes into a new Chinese-government-sponsored television drama, so short that it would have been easy to miss: The head of a bus company in Wuhan, the city where the coronavirus outbreak began, asks his drivers if they are willing to make emergency runs during the city’s lockdown. A line of volunteers forms. None are women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Our Poll* Shows Close Race for Senate in Montana
description: *The survey erred in listing the Green Party, but it’s still clear that Daines and Bullock are in a tight contest.
content: A New York Times/Siena College poll of Montana shows a close race for Senate. But it has an important flaw: It named Green Party candidates who won’t be on the ballot this November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: The Nation Lost a Titan. Brooklyn Lost a Native Daughter.
description: Ruth Bader Ginsburg — “Kiki” to her Brooklyn family — was a product of the borough’s public schools and synagogues. She is revered on her home ground.
content: Ruth Bader Ginsburg was a child of Brooklyn long before she was Notorious — daughter of Jewish immigrants, graduate of P.S. 238 and James Madison High School (class of 1950), cheerleader known as Kiki Bader, member of the East Midwood Jewish Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and David McCabe
title: U.S. Judge Temporarily Halts Trump’s WeChat Ban
description: The order is a setback in the president’s efforts to block a Chinese social media app that he has labeled a national security threat. The ban had been set to go into effect on Sunday night.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge has issued an injunction against President Trump’s executive order effectively banning the Chinese social media app WeChat from operating in the United States after midnight on Sunday, presenting at least a temporary setback in the president’s efforts to block an app that he has labeled a national security threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Anderson
title: How One District Got Its Students Back Into Classrooms
description: Cajon Valley in California is doing something that many lower-income districts have postponed: offering in-person instruction.
content: When schools shuttered in March, David Miyashiro, the superintendent of the Cajon Valley Union School District, immediately started connecting with families and teachers. During hundreds of calls, Zoom meetings and socially distanced in-person gatherings, he heard desperate pleas from poor parents torn between work and home instruction, or who needed support for high-needs students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: What to Watch For at the 2020 Emmy Awards
description: Jimmy Kimmel will host the ceremony as viewers — and the nominees — tune in from home.
content: Lights! Camera! And … let’s hope the Wi-Fi works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Emmys 2020: Highlights and Analysis
description: Our writers watched the 72nd Emmy Awards on Sunday and weighed in on the audience-less and remote ceremony, the winners and their favorite (and least favorite) moments of the show.
content: Our writers watched the 72nd Emmy Awards on Sunday and weighed in on the audience-less and remote ceremony, the winners and their favorite (and least favorite) moments of the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl, Caroline Kim, Drew Jordan and Arielle Ray
title: How an Oregon Wildfire Became One of the Most Destructive
description: The Almeda fire left a path of destruction as it tore through the Rogue Valley in southern Oregon. About 24 hours after it started, an estimated 2,350 homes had been left in ashes. We used satellite images, videos and social media posts to track what happened.
content: The Almeda fire left a path of destruction as it tore through the Rogue Valley in southern Oregon. About 24 hours after it started, an estimated 2,350 homes had been left in ashes. We used satellite images, videos and social media posts to track what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters, The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Vigils for Justice Ginsburg Held Across the Country
description: Mourners gathered around courthouses across the nation on Saturday to remember the late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: Mourners gathered around courthouses across the nation on Saturday to remember the late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
